Definition: Soil is the uppermost layer of the Earth that supports plant growth. It consists of minerals, organic matter, water, and air. Healthy soil provides nutrients, stores water, and supports biodiversity essential for agriculture.

Soil fertility refers to the soil's ability to supply essential nutrients to crops in adequate amounts. It depends on soil texture, organic matter, pH, and microbial activity. Fertile soil ensures sustainable crop yields and ecosystem balance.

Soil erosion is the removal of the top fertile layer of soil by wind or water. It reduces soil productivity and leads to sedimentation in water bodies. Conservation methods like contour farming, mulching, and afforestation help prevent erosion.

Irrigation is the artificial application of water to soil or land to support crop growth. It compensates for inadequate rainfall and improves productivity. Efficient irrigation systems prevent water waste and soil salinization.

Drip irrigation delivers water directly to plant roots through pipes and emitters. It minimizes evaporation and water loss, increases efficiency, and is ideal for water-scarce regions and horticultural crops.
Sprinkler irrigation distributes water through pipes and nozzles that simulate natural rainfall. It provides uniform water distribution, reduces soil erosion, and is suitable for uneven terrains.
Mulching covers the soil with materials such as straw, leaves, or compost to conserve moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate temperature. It enhances soil structure and reduces erosion.
Crop rotation is the practice of growing different crops in the same field in sequential seasons. It prevents nutrient depletion, controls pests, and improves soil fertility naturally.
Organic farming is a method that avoids synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. It relies on compost, crop rotation, and biological pest control to maintain soil health and produce chemical-free food.

Agroforestry integrates trees and shrubs into crop and livestock systems. It improves biodiversity, prevents soil erosion, enhances carbon sequestration, and provides additional income from timber and fruits.

Vermicomposting is the process of using earthworms to convert organic waste into nutrient-rich compost called vermicompost. It improves soil aeration, enhances microbial activity, and provides a natural fertilizer for sustainable farming.

Composting is the biological decomposition of organic waste such as crop residues and manure into nutrient-rich material that improves soil structure and fertility. It reduces waste and supports sustainable agriculture.

A biofertilizer contains living microorganisms that enhance nutrient availability to plants. Examples include Rhizobium, Azotobacter, and Azospirillum, which fix nitrogen and improve soil health naturally.
Fertilizers are substances added to soil to supply essential nutrients for plant growth. They can be organic or inorganic, and balanced application improves yield and soil productivity.
Manure is decomposed animal dung or plant waste used to improve soil fertility. It adds organic matter, enhances moisture retention, and promotes microbial activity.
Cover crops are plants grown mainly to protect soil rather than for harvest. They prevent erosion, suppress weeds, improve organic matter, and maintain soil fertility.
Green manure refers to crops grown and plowed into the soil to increase organic matter and nutrients. Common green manure crops include legumes that fix nitrogen naturally.
A pesticide is a chemical or biological substance used to control pests, weeds, or plant diseases. Responsible use minimizes environmental harm and ensures crop safety.
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) combines biological, cultural, physical, and chemical methods to manage pests economically while minimizing environmental damage.
Rainwater harvesting is the collection and storage of rainwater for irrigation or domestic use. It conserves water, reduces dependence on groundwater, and improves sustainability.
Contour farming involves plowing and planting crops along the natural contours of the land. It reduces soil erosion, enhances water infiltration, and conserves nutrients.
Terracing creates leveled platforms on sloped land to prevent soil erosion and runoff. It allows efficient water retention and cultivation on hilly terrain.
Sustainable livestock management focuses on efficient feed use, animal welfare, and waste recycling. It reduces methane emissions and supports ecological balance.
Biodiversity refers to the variety of living organisms within ecosystems. It supports pollination, pest control, and ecological resilience essential for sustainable agriculture.
Carbon sequestration is the process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon dioxide in soil, vegetation, or biomass to mitigate climate change impacts.
Hydroponics is a method of growing plants without soil, using nutrient-rich water. It saves water, increases yield, and allows year-round production.
Aquaponics integrates aquaculture (fish farming) and hydroponics in a closed-loop system where fish waste provides nutrients for plants, and plants purify water for fish.
Biogas is a renewable fuel produced by anaerobic digestion of organic waste. It generates energy for cooking or electricity and provides nutrient-rich slurry as fertilizer.
Renewable energy in agriculture includes solar, wind, and biogas power. It reduces carbon emissions, lowers costs, and promotes sustainable rural development.
Climate-smart agriculture (CSA) includes practices that enhance productivity, resilience, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to adapt to climate change.
Water conservation in agriculture focuses on efficient use and management of water resources through drip irrigation, rainwater harvesting, and soil moisture retention.

Organic pest control uses natural substances and biological methods like neem oil, garlic extract, and beneficial insects to manage pests. It avoids harmful chemicals and preserves ecological balance.
Permaculture is a design system that mimics natural ecosystems to create self-sustaining agricultural environments. It focuses on diversity, resilience, and efficient resource use.
No-till farming is a conservation practice where crops are planted directly into undisturbed soil. It improves soil structure, reduces erosion, and enhances carbon storage.

Zero Budget Natural Farming (ZBNF) is an Indian method that eliminates external chemical inputs. It promotes natural fertilizers like cow dung, urine-based bio-inputs, and local resources for low-cost farming.
Deforestation is the large-scale removal of forest cover for agriculture or development. It leads to habitat loss, biodiversity decline, and contributes to global warming.
Agroecology applies ecological principles to agriculture for sustainable food systems. It integrates biodiversity, soil health, and traditional knowledge for long-term productivity.
Pollinators such as bees, butterflies, and birds are essential for plant reproduction. They increase crop yields and biodiversity but are threatened by pesticides and habitat loss.
Nutrient management ensures the right balance of fertilizers and organic inputs to meet crop needs while reducing waste and pollution.
Soil testing analyzes nutrient content, pH, and structure to guide fertilizer use. It helps farmers improve yields and prevent soil degradation.
Food security ensures that all people have reliable access to sufficient, safe, and nutritious food. Sustainable farming practices are key to achieving it.
Precision agriculture uses GPS, sensors, drones, and data analytics to optimize water, fertilizer, and pesticide application for maximum efficiency and minimum waste.
Farm mechanization involves the use of machinery such as tractors, harvesters, and irrigation systems to increase efficiency, reduce labor, and boost productivity.
Crop diversification means growing multiple crop species on the same farm to spread risk, improve soil health, and increase income stability.
Integrated nutrient management combines organic, inorganic, and biological inputs to sustain soil fertility and reduce dependence on chemical fertilizers.
Sustainable water management focuses on conserving water through efficient irrigation, rainwater harvesting, and recycling to ensure long-term availability.
Agro-tourism combines farming with tourism, allowing visitors to experience rural life and providing farmers with additional income and awareness opportunities.
Regenerative agriculture restores soil health, biodiversity, and water cycles through minimal tillage, cover crops, and composting to reverse environmental degradation.
Sustainable forestry manages forests to meet current needs while preserving biodiversity and resources for future generations.
Carbon footprint measures the total greenhouse gas emissions caused by human activities, including agriculture. Reducing it helps mitigate climate change.
Organic certification verifies that a farm follows standards prohibiting synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, and GMOs, ensuring genuine organic produce.
A seed bank stores and preserves seeds of different plant species for future use, protecting genetic diversity and ensuring crop resilience against disasters.
Drought-resistant crops require less water and withstand dry conditions, helping farmers adapt to climate change and water scarcity.
A greenhouse is a structure made of transparent materials like glass or plastic that allows sunlight in and traps heat, creating a controlled environment for growing crops year-round.
Precision irrigation uses sensors and data analysis to deliver the exact amount of water required by each crop, minimizing waste and improving efficiency.
Sustainable aquaculture focuses on responsible fish farming that minimizes environmental impact, maintains biodiversity, and ensures long-term productivity.
The organic certification process verifies that farming practices meet organic standards, ensuring crops are grown without synthetic chemicals or genetically modified organisms.
Water harvesting ponds collect and store rainwater for irrigation and livestock use, improving water availability during dry seasons.
Agro-meteorology studies the relationship between weather and agriculture, helping farmers plan sowing, irrigation, and harvesting based on climate data.
Biological pest control uses natural predators, parasites, or microorganisms to manage pest populations safely and sustainably.
Value addition increases the market value of agricultural products through processing, packaging, or branding, improving farmers’ income and reducing waste.
Farm waste recycling converts crop residues and animal waste into compost, biofertilizer, or biogas, promoting sustainability and reducing pollution.
Solar farming uses solar panels to generate renewable energy for irrigation, processing, and other agricultural operations, reducing dependency on fossil fuels.
Renewable irrigation pumps are powered by solar or wind energy, providing sustainable water supply solutions for farmers in remote areas.
Manure management involves the safe handling, storage, and utilization of animal waste as organic fertilizer or biogas feedstock to prevent pollution and enhance soil fertility.
Agri cooperatives are farmer-owned organizations that pool resources for better marketing, input purchasing, and price negotiation, improving farmers’ collective strength.
A smart greenhouse uses automation, IoT sensors, and climate control systems to maintain optimal growing conditions and improve crop yield and quality.
Vertical farming grows crops in stacked layers, often in controlled indoor environments, saving space, water, and energy while enabling urban food production.
Urban agriculture refers to growing food in and around cities through rooftop gardens, vertical systems, and community farms, improving food access and sustainability.
The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are global objectives adopted by the United Nations to promote environmental sustainability, food security, and social equity.
Food processing involves transforming raw agricultural products into consumable forms through techniques like cleaning, drying, and packaging to increase shelf life and value.
Agri marketing includes all activities involved in moving agricultural products from farm to consumer, including storage, transportation, grading, and pricing.
Farm safety involves preventing accidents and injuries on farms by promoting safe equipment use, proper training, and protective measures for workers.
Women in agriculture play vital roles in crop production, livestock care, and agribusiness. Empowering them improves productivity and rural livelihoods.
Encouraging youth participation in agriculture introduces innovation, technology adoption, and sustainable farming practices for future food security.
Climate adaptation in agriculture involves adjusting practices like crop choice, irrigation, and timing to minimize the effects of climate change.
Post-harvest management covers all activities from harvesting to storage, processing, and marketing, reducing losses and maintaining product quality.
Crop insurance protects farmers against financial losses due to natural disasters, pests, or price fluctuations, ensuring income stability.
Rainfed agriculture depends solely on rainfall for crop growth, requiring water conservation and drought-resistant varieties to sustain productivity.
Pasture management involves maintaining healthy grasslands for livestock by controlling grazing, rotating pastures, and reseeding degraded areas.
Livestock feed includes natural forage, grains, and formulated supplements that provide essential nutrients for animal growth and milk or meat production.
Water footprint measures the total amount of freshwater used directly and indirectly to produce agricultural goods, helping evaluate sustainability.
Nutrient cycling is the natural movement and reuse of nutrients like nitrogen and carbon between soil, plants, and atmosphere, maintaining ecosystem balance.
Biochar is a carbon-rich material produced from biomass through pyrolysis. It improves soil fertility, water retention, and carbon sequestration.
Soil microbes are microorganisms such as bacteria and fungi that decompose organic matter, fix nitrogen, and enhance soil fertility for sustainable farming.
Organic seed production ensures that seeds are developed using natural, chemical-free methods. It maintains genetic purity and supports organic farming systems.
Agro-waste management focuses on recycling farm residues, processing biomass, and converting waste into valuable by-products like compost and bioenergy.
Crop yield forecasting uses data models, remote sensing, and AI to predict crop output, helping policymakers and farmers plan for supply and food security.
Agri finance provides loans, insurance, and subsidies to farmers for purchasing inputs, machinery, or land, supporting agricultural sustainability and innovation.
Sustainable packaging uses biodegradable, compostable, or recyclable materials to reduce environmental impact in the storage and transportation of food products.
Agri education provides knowledge and skills related to modern and traditional farming practices, promoting innovation and youth engagement in agriculture.
Wastewater reuse involves treating and reusing agricultural or domestic water for irrigation, reducing freshwater demand and preventing pollution.
Crop residue management turns leftover plant materials after harvest into compost or biomass fuel instead of burning, reducing pollution and improving soil health.
Renewable fertilizers are produced from organic waste, algae, or microbes, providing an eco-friendly alternative to synthetic chemical fertilizers.
Farmer Producer Organizations (FPOs) are collective groups that help small farmers access markets, negotiate better prices, and share resources for improved profitability.

Seed germination is the process by which a seed sprouts and begins to grow into a plant. It requires moisture, oxygen, and the right temperature. Healthy germination ensures strong crop establishment.
Transpiration is the loss of water vapor from plant leaves through tiny pores called stomata. It helps in cooling plants and transporting nutrients. It plays a key role in the water cycle.

Photosynthesis is the process where green plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to produce food. It releases oxygen into the atmosphere. This process is essential for plant growth and life on Earth.
Soil compaction occurs when soil particles are pressed together, reducing pore space. It restricts root growth and water infiltration. Proper tillage helps prevent soil compaction.
Crop spacing refers to the distance maintained between plants while sowing. Proper spacing improves air circulation and sunlight exposure. It reduces competition for nutrients and water.
Plant nutrients are essential chemical elements required for plant growth. These include nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and micronutrients. Balanced nutrient supply improves crop health and yield.
Soil moisture is the water content present in the soil. It affects seed germination and plant growth. Proper soil moisture management prevents crop stress and yield loss.
Grafting is a horticultural technique where tissues of two plants are joined. It combines desirable traits such as disease resistance and improved yield. It is widely used in fruit crops.
Pruning is the practice of trimming unnecessary plant parts to improve growth. It increases air flow and sunlight penetration. It helps in better fruit and flower production.
Weed management is the control of unwanted plants that compete with crops. Methods include manual weeding, mulching, and herbicides. Effective management improves crop productivity.
Intercropping is growing two or more crops in the same field simultaneously. It improves resource use efficiency and reduces pest risks. Farmers use it to increase overall yield.
Mixed farming involves growing crops and rearing livestock on the same farm. Animal waste improves soil fertility. It increases farm income stability.
Soil salinity is the accumulation of salts in soil. It reduces plant growth and crop yield. Proper drainage and salt-tolerant crops help manage salinity.
Plant breeding is the science of developing improved plant varieties. It enhances yield, disease resistance, and climate adaptability. It supports food security and sustainability.
Crop maturity refers to the stage when crops are ready to harvest. Harvesting at the right time ensures better quality and yield. Early or late harvesting reduces productivity.
Irrigation scheduling is the process of deciding when and how much water to apply. It prevents water wastage and crop stress. It improves water-use efficiency.
Soil organic carbon is the carbon stored in soil as organic matter. It improves soil structure and fertility. Higher levels enhance water retention and crop growth.
Plant phenology studies the timing of plant growth stages. It helps farmers plan irrigation and fertilization. It is affected by climate and weather patterns.
Fodder crops are grown to feed livestock. They provide essential nutrients for animal health. Proper fodder management improves milk and meat production.
Crop residue burning is the practice of burning leftover crop materials. It causes air pollution and nutrient loss. Sustainable alternatives include composting and mulching.
Agro-climatic zones classify regions based on climate and soil. They help determine suitable crops for each area. This improves crop planning and yield.
Seed treatment involves applying chemicals or bio-agents to seeds before sowing. It protects seeds from pests and diseases. It improves germination and early growth.
Plant protection involves preventing crops from pests and diseases. It includes biological, chemical, and cultural practices. Proper protection ensures healthy yields.
Crop lodging occurs when plants bend or fall over due to wind or weak stems. It reduces yield and harvesting efficiency. Proper nutrition and spacing help prevent it.
Soil aeration improves oxygen availability in soil. It enhances root respiration and microbial activity. It improves plant health and productivity.
Drip fertigation combines irrigation and fertilizer application through drip systems. It ensures precise nutrient delivery. It improves fertilizer use efficiency.
Mulch farming involves covering soil with organic or plastic materials. It conserves moisture and controls weeds. It improves soil health and crop yield.
Crop thinning is the removal of excess seedlings. It reduces competition between plants. It promotes healthy plant development.
Bio-pesticides are pest control agents derived from natural materials. They are environmentally safe and target specific pests. Examples include neem-based products.
Polyculture is growing multiple crop species together. It enhances biodiversity and reduces pest outbreaks. It improves farm resilience.
Seed viability is the ability of a seed to germinate and grow. High viability ensures good crop establishment. Proper storage preserves seed viability.
Soil crusting is the formation of a hard layer on the soil surface. It reduces water infiltration and seedling emergence. Light tillage prevents crusting.
Rainfed cropping depends entirely on rainfall for crop growth. It requires moisture conservation practices. It is common in dryland areas.
Precision seeding places seeds at optimal depth and spacing. It improves uniform germination and yield. It reduces seed wastage.
Soil tilth refers to the physical condition of soil. Good tilth promotes root growth and water movement. Proper tillage improves soil tilth.
Plant hardening is the process of gradually exposing seedlings to outdoor conditions. It improves plant survival after transplanting. It reduces transplant shock.
Crop shading reduces soil temperature and moisture loss. It helps in weed suppression. Shade-tolerant crops benefit from shading.
Watershed management involves conserving water and soil in a drainage area. It reduces runoff and erosion. It improves water availability.
Plant spacing ensures optimal distance between plants. It reduces competition and disease spread. It maximizes crop yield.
Dryland farming is practiced in regions with low rainfall. It uses moisture conservation techniques. It helps in sustainable crop production.
Fallowing is leaving land uncultivated for a period. It helps restore soil fertility and moisture. It improves long-term productivity.
Soil amendment is the addition of materials to improve soil quality. Examples include compost and lime. It enhances soil structure and fertility.
Crop monitoring involves observing crop health and growth. It helps in early detection of pests and nutrient deficiencies. It improves crop management decisions.
Soil pH is the measure of soil acidity or alkalinity. It affects nutrient availability and microbial activity. Maintaining proper pH helps crops absorb nutrients efficiently.
Micronutrients are essential elements like zinc, iron, copper, and boron required in small quantities by plants. They support enzymatic reactions and healthy plant growth.
Macronutrients are nutrients required in large quantities such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. They are vital for leaf, root, and flowering development.
Humus is the dark, organic component of soil formed by decomposed plant and animal matter. It improves soil structure, moisture retention, and nutrient availability.
Soil profile is a vertical section of soil showing different layers or horizons. Each layer has unique physical and chemical properties that influence plant growth.
Topsoil is the uppermost fertile layer of soil. It contains the highest amount of organic matter and microorganisms. It is essential for crop production.
Subsoil is the layer beneath topsoil. It contains fewer nutrients but stores minerals and water. Strong roots often penetrate this layer.
Weathering is the breakdown of rocks into smaller particles by physical, chemical, or biological processes. It plays a role in soil formation over time.
Pedology is the scientific study of soil formation, classification, and mapping. It helps understand soil behavior and land use planning.
Edaphology is the study of how soil influences plant growth. It focuses on soil-plant relationships and nutrient availability.
Soil texture refers to the proportion of sand, silt, and clay particles in soil. It affects water retention, drainage, and root penetration.
Soil structure is the arrangement of soil particles into aggregates. Good structure improves aeration, water movement, and root growth.
Capillary action is the movement of water through small soil pores against gravity. It helps distribute moisture to plant roots.
Field capacity is the amount of soil moisture retained after excess water drains away. It represents the optimal water level for plant use.
Permanent wilting point is the soil moisture level at which plants can no longer extract water. At this stage, plants begin to wilt irreversibly.
Soil porosity is the percentage of pore spaces in soil. It determines the soil’s ability to hold air and water for roots and microbes.
Soil bulk density is the mass of soil in a given volume. High bulk density restricts root growth and water movement.
Infiltration rate is the speed at which water enters the soil surface. High infiltration reduces runoff and erosion.
Percolation is the downward movement of water through soil layers. It helps recharge groundwater.
Water table is the upper level of groundwater stored in soil or rock. It influences irrigation and crop root depth.
Salinization is the accumulation of soluble salts in soil due to poor drainage or over-irrigation. It reduces soil fertility and crop yield.
Alkaline soil has a high pH value. It can reduce the availability of micronutrients to plants.
Acidic soil has a low pH level. It may increase the solubility of toxic metals and reduce crop productivity.
Leaching is the downward movement of nutrients with water through soil. It can cause nutrient loss, especially nitrogen.
Evapotranspiration is the combined loss of water from soil evaporation and plant transpiration. It helps estimate crop water requirements.
Hardpan is a compacted soil layer that restricts root penetration and water movement. Deep plowing helps break hardpan.
Ploughing is the mechanical turning of soil to prepare land for sowing. It improves aeration and loosens compacted soil.
Harrowing is the process of breaking soil clods after ploughing. It creates a fine seedbed for planting.
Levelling is the practice of making the soil surface even. It helps in uniform irrigation and crop establishment.
Seedbed preparation involves creating suitable soil conditions for seed germination. It includes loosening, leveling, and enriching soil.
Broadcasting is the method of scattering seeds uniformly over the soil surface. It is simple but less precise than line sowing.
Line sowing is planting seeds in straight rows at regular intervals. It improves spacing, aeration, and crop management.
Transplanting is shifting seedlings from nursery beds to the main field. It ensures uniform plant population and better crop establishment.
Nursery management involves growing and caring for young seedlings before transplanting. It ensures healthy plant growth.
Rabi crops are grown in winter season and harvested in spring. Examples include wheat, mustard, and barley.
Kharif crops are grown during the monsoon season. Examples include rice, maize, and cotton.
Zaid crops are grown between Rabi and Kharif seasons. These are usually short-duration summer crops.
Hybrid seeds are produced by crossing two genetically different parent plants. They give higher yield and better disease resistance.
Open-pollinated varieties are crops that reproduce naturally. Farmers can save and reuse their seeds for future planting.
Seed dormancy is a temporary state where seeds do not germinate despite favorable conditions. It prevents germination at unsuitable times.
Hard water contains high levels of dissolved minerals. It may cause salt buildup in soil over time.
Surface irrigation applies water by flowing it over the field surface. It is simple but less efficient in water use.
Subsurface irrigation delivers water below the soil surface. It reduces evaporation and improves water efficiency.
Furrow irrigation supplies water through small channels between crop rows. It is widely used for row crops.
Check basin irrigation divides fields into small basins to hold water. It ensures uniform water distribution.
Cropping pattern is the sequence and arrangement of crops grown over time in a particular area. It helps in effective resource use.
Monocropping is growing the same crop year after year. It can lead to nutrient depletion and pest buildup.
Multiple cropping is growing more than one crop in the same field in a year. It increases land productivity.
Relay cropping involves planting a second crop before the first crop is harvested. It maximizes resource use efficiency.
Strip cropping is growing crops in alternating strips. It reduces erosion and improves soil conservation.
Buffer strips are vegetated areas along field edges. They reduce nutrient runoff and protect water bodies.
Windbreaks are rows of trees or shrubs planted to reduce wind speed. They protect crops and prevent soil erosion.
Shelterbelts are wide windbreaks used to protect large areas of farmland. They improve microclimate for crops.
Land degradation is the decline in soil quality due to erosion, salinity, or nutrient loss. It reduces agricultural productivity.
Desertification is the process where fertile land becomes desert due to climate change and poor land management.
Agro-inputs include seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and machinery used in farming. Proper management improves productivity.
Crop physiology studies how plants grow and function. It helps improve crop management techniques.
Soil fertility management involves maintaining nutrient levels in soil. It ensures sustainable crop production.
Earthing up is the practice of piling soil around plant bases. It supports plant stability and root development.
Ridge and furrow farming creates raised beds and channels. It improves drainage and root aeration.
Crop stand refers to the number of healthy plants per unit area. Good crop stand ensures high yield potential.
Plant population density is the number of plants grown per unit area. Proper density avoids competition and improves yield.
Soil reclamation restores degraded soil by removing salts and improving structure. It makes land productive again.
Land capability is the ability of land to support specific types of use. It guides sustainable land management.
Soil conservation includes practices that prevent soil degradation. It protects long-term agricultural productivity.
Rain shadow effect occurs when mountains block rainfall to certain regions. It affects crop planning and water availability.
Agro-input subsidy is financial support given to farmers for purchasing seeds, fertilizers, or tools. It reduces production costs.
Farm gate price is the price farmers receive for their produce directly at the farm. It affects farm income and market planning.
Minimum support price (MSP) is the government-set price to protect farmers from market fluctuations. It ensures minimum income stability.
Crop calendar shows the timeline of planting, growing, and harvesting of crops. It helps in efficient farm planning.
Agro-advisory services provide farmers with guidance on weather, pest control, and crop management. They improve farm decision-making.
Farm credit is financial assistance given to farmers. It helps in purchasing inputs and expanding farm operations.
Land tenure refers to the rights of ownership or use of land. Secure tenure encourages better land management.
Subsistence farming is growing food mainly for family consumption. It focuses on self-sufficiency rather than commercial profit.
Commercial farming is crop and livestock production for market sale. It focuses on profit and large-scale production.
Plant growth regulators are chemicals that influence plant growth processes. They control flowering, rooting, and fruit development.
Crop simulation models use computer programs to predict crop growth and yield. They assist in planning and risk assessment.
Soil water potential measures how tightly water is held in soil. It influences plant water uptake.
Plant turgidity is the firmness of plant cells due to water pressure. It is essential for plant structure and growth.
Agro-ecosystem is the ecological system created by agricultural activities. It includes crops, soil, water, and organisms.
Soil horizon is a distinct layer of soil with specific characteristics. Each horizon plays a role in plant root development.
Cation exchange capacity (CEC) measures soil’s ability to hold and exchange nutrients. High CEC indicates better fertility.
Soil conditioners are materials added to improve soil structure. Examples include gypsum and compost.
Deep plowing loosens soil at greater depth. It improves root penetration and water infiltration.
Crop scouting is regular field inspection to detect pests, diseases, and nutrient deficiencies. It improves timely farm management.
Plant canopy is the upper layer of leaves formed by crops. It affects light interception and photosynthesis.
Agroforestry buffer is a protective zone using trees around farms. It prevents erosion and improves biodiversity.
Rhizosphere is the soil region surrounding plant roots. It is rich in microbial activity and nutrient exchange.
Soil buffering capacity is the ability of soil to resist changes in pH. It helps maintain stable soil conditions. This protects plants from sudden nutrient imbalances.
Mineralization is the process where microorganisms convert organic nutrients into inorganic forms. It makes nutrients available for plant uptake. This process is vital for natural soil fertility.
Immobilization is when soil microbes absorb nutrients and make them temporarily unavailable to plants. It occurs during decomposition of high-carbon materials. It balances nutrient cycling.
Denitrification is the process of converting nitrates into nitrogen gas by soil bacteria. It reduces available nitrogen in soil. It mostly occurs in waterlogged conditions.
Nitrogen fixation is the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen into plant-usable forms by bacteria. It increases soil nitrogen levels naturally. Leguminous plants commonly perform this function.
Rhizobium is a beneficial bacterium that lives in legume root nodules. It helps fix atmospheric nitrogen. This improves soil fertility without chemical fertilizers.
Mycorrhiza are fungi that form a symbiotic relationship with plant roots. They increase nutrient and water absorption. They also improve plant resistance to stress.
Soil respiration is the release of carbon dioxide by roots and microorganisms. It indicates soil biological activity. Healthy soils show balanced respiration rates.
Aggregate stability is the strength of soil clumps. Good stability reduces erosion and improves water infiltration. Organic matter helps improve soil aggregates.
Soil color indicates organic matter and mineral content. Dark soils usually contain more humus. Color helps in soil classification.
Texture triangle is a chart used to classify soil based on sand, silt, and clay content. It helps predict water retention and drainage properties.
Soil survey is the systematic study and mapping of soil types. It helps in land-use planning and crop selection. Governments use it for agricultural planning.
Laser land leveling uses laser-guided equipment to level fields. It improves water distribution and reduces irrigation losses. It enhances crop uniformity.
Seed drill is a machine that places seeds at correct depth and spacing. It ensures better germination. It saves seed and labor.
Threshing is the process of separating grains from harvested crops. Modern threshers increase speed and reduce grain loss. It improves post-harvest efficiency.
Winnowing is the separation of grain from chaff using wind. It helps clean harvested produce. It is a traditional yet effective method.
Crop harvesting is the cutting and collecting of mature crops. Timely harvesting ensures maximum yield and quality. Delayed harvesting causes losses.
Moisture stress occurs when plants do not receive enough water. It reduces growth and yield. Proper irrigation management prevents stress.
Heat stress happens when high temperatures damage plant tissues. It affects flowering and pollination. Shade nets and mulching can reduce damage.
Cold stress occurs when low temperatures damage plant cells. Sensitive crops suffer reduced growth. Greenhouses help protect plants.
Photoperiodism is the response of plants to the length of day and night. It influences flowering and growth patterns. Crop varieties differ in sensitivity.
Vernalization is the process of exposing seeds or plants to cold temperatures. It stimulates flowering. It is common in winter crops.
Crop dormancy is a resting stage when growth slows. It helps plants survive unfavorable conditions. It resumes when conditions improve.
Seed pelleting is coating seeds with protective and nutrient-rich materials. It improves seed handling and germination. It also reduces seedling diseases.
Soil fumigation is the application of chemicals to control soil-borne pests. It sterilizes harmful organisms. It is used in high-value crop production.
Trap crops are plants grown to attract pests away from main crops. They help in natural pest management. This reduces pesticide use.
Allelopathy is the chemical inhibition of one plant by another. Some plants release substances that suppress weeds. It is used in sustainable farming.
Organic mulches include straw, leaves, and compost. They decompose and enrich the soil. They also conserve moisture.
Plastic mulches are synthetic sheets used to cover soil. They reduce weed growth and retain heat. They are common in vegetable farming.
Hardening of seedlings prepares young plants for field conditions. It increases resistance to temperature and water stress. It improves survival rate.
Root zone is the soil area explored by plant roots. It stores water and nutrients needed by plants. Healthy root zones improve yield.
Plant establishment is the successful survival and initial growth of seedlings. It determines crop stand and productivity. Good soil and water management help establishment.
Crop coefficient is used to estimate water requirements. It varies with crop type and growth stage. It helps in irrigation planning.
Agrohydrology studies water movement in agricultural lands. It helps in managing irrigation and drainage. It supports sustainable water use.
Soil water balance is the relationship between water input and output. It helps estimate irrigation needs. It prevents water logging and drought stress.
Waterlogging is the saturation of soil with excess water. It reduces oxygen in soil. It harms root growth and crop health.
Drainage systems remove excess water from fields. They prevent waterlogging and root diseases. They improve soil aeration.
Crop rotation intensity refers to how frequently crops are changed in a field. Higher intensity improves soil health and reduces pests. It enhances sustainability.
Farming systems are the combination of crops, livestock, and management practices. They define farm productivity and sustainability. Different regions follow different systems.
Agro-based industries use agricultural raw materials for production. Examples include sugar mills and rice mills. They add value to farm produce.
Cold storage is a temperature-controlled facility for storing perishable crops. It reduces spoilage and extends shelf life. It improves market stability.
Grading is the sorting of agricultural produce based on size and quality. It improves market value. It helps meet export standards.
Sorting is the removal of damaged or inferior produce. It enhances product quality. It reduces post-harvest losses.
Packaging protects farm produce during transport and storage. Good packaging increases shelf life. It improves visual appeal in markets.
Ripening chambers control temperature and gases to ripen fruits uniformly. They improve quality and reduce spoilage. They are used for commercial fruit markets.
Supply chain management controls the flow of agricultural products from farm to consumer. It reduces delays and losses. It improves food availability.
Market yard is a physical place where farmers sell their produce. It connects farmers with traders. It ensures fair price discovery.
Electronic trading allows online buying and selling of agricultural products. It improves transparency. It gives farmers access to wider markets.
Commodity exchange is a platform for trading agricultural goods. It helps in price discovery and risk management. It stabilizes market fluctuations.
Price support schemes protect farmers from low market prices. Governments intervene to stabilize farm income. This encourages crop production.
Soil solarization uses sunlight to heat soil and destroy pests. Plastic sheets trap solar energy. It is an eco-friendly pest control method.
Floating agriculture grows crops on floating beds of vegetation. It is practiced in flood-prone areas. It helps utilize waterlogged lands.
Dry seeding is sowing seeds in dry soil before rainfall. It reduces labor and water use. It is common in dryland farming.
Direct seeding plants seeds directly in the field without transplanting. It saves time and labor. It reduces transplant shock.
Power tiller is a small agricultural machine used for land preparation. It is suitable for small farms. It reduces human effort.
Combine harvester performs reaping, threshing, and winnowing in one operation. It saves time and labor. It increases harvesting efficiency.
Crop insurance premium is the amount paid by farmers for insurance coverage. Government subsidies often reduce the cost. It provides financial protection.
Plant stress detection identifies early signs of nutrient or water deficiency. Sensors and imaging tools are used. It prevents yield loss.
Bio-stimulants are substances that enhance plant growth naturally. They improve nutrient uptake and stress tolerance. They are eco-friendly.
Cryopreservation is the storage of plant material at extremely low temperatures. It preserves genetic resources. It is used in seed banks.
Apiculture is the scientific management of honey bees. It improves pollination. It produces honey and other by-products.
Sericulture is the rearing of silkworms for silk production. It supports rural livelihoods. It is an important agro-based industry.
Mushroom cultivation is the growing of edible fungi. It requires controlled temperature and humidity. It provides high nutritional food.
Seed certification verifies the quality of seeds. It ensures purity and high germination rates. It helps farmers get reliable planting material.
Hardy crop varieties are resistant to harsh climatic conditions. They tolerate heat, cold, and drought. They ensure stable production.
Biofortification increases the nutritional value of crops. It enhances vitamins and minerals in food. It helps combat malnutrition.
Soil alkalinity refers to high pH conditions in soil. It affects nutrient availability and crop performance. Management includes gypsum application and organic matter addition.
Base saturation is the percentage of soil bases like calcium and magnesium. It indicates soil fertility status. Higher saturation usually means better nutrient availability.
Clay loam is a soil texture containing balanced sand, silt, and clay. It holds nutrients and water well. It is suitable for many crops.
Sandy loam is a light-textured soil with good drainage. It warms quickly and is easy to cultivate. Irrigation is needed frequently due to low water retention.
Soil cracking occurs when clay-rich soils dry and shrink. It can damage plant roots. Proper moisture management reduces cracking.
Hydraulic conductivity measures how easily water moves through soil. High values indicate good drainage. It affects irrigation planning.
Soil compaction layer is a hardened zone restricting root growth. It reduces air and water movement. Deep tillage helps break it.
Anaerobic conditions occur when soil lacks oxygen. This harms root respiration. Good drainage prevents anaerobic soil states.
Aerobic conditions exist when soil has sufficient oxygen. They favor beneficial microbes. Healthy plant roots develop under these conditions.
Soil temperature influences seed germination and root growth. Warmer soils speed up microbial activity. Mulching helps regulate temperature.
Thermal time measures heat accumulation required for crop growth. It helps predict crop maturity. Also called growing degree days.
Growing degree days measure accumulated heat for plant development. Farmers use it to plan harvest timing. It improves yield prediction.
Crop coefficient curve shows crop water demand at different growth stages. It helps in accurate irrigation scheduling. It improves water efficiency.
Spray drift is the movement of pesticide droplets away from target plants. It can harm nearby crops. Proper nozzle and wind control reduce drift.
Soil sponge effect describes soil’s ability to absorb and store water. Organic matter improves this effect. It reduces runoff and erosion.
Crusting injury occurs when seedlings cannot break through hardened soil surface. It reduces plant population. Light irrigation helps soften crust.
Plant vigor refers to the strength and growth rate of plants. Vigorous plants resist pests better. Proper nutrition improves vigor.
Root pruning limits excessive root growth. It balances shoot and root development. Common in nursery management.
Light interception is the capture of sunlight by plant leaves. It affects photosynthesis. Proper spacing improves light use.
Leaf area index measures leaf surface area per ground area. Higher values mean more photosynthesis potential. It influences yield capacity.
Canopy temperature indicates plant water stress. Higher temperature suggests drought stress. Used in precision irrigation.
Crop residue cover is the protective layer of leftover plant material. It reduces erosion and conserves moisture. Important in conservation farming.
Soil biodiversity is the variety of organisms in soil. It supports nutrient cycling. Healthy biodiversity improves soil fertility.
Biological nitrogen fixers are organisms converting nitrogen gas into usable forms. They reduce synthetic fertilizer needs. Common in legumes.
Nodule formation occurs in legume roots due to symbiotic bacteria. It enables nitrogen fixation. It improves soil nitrogen levels.
Agro-silviculture is the integration of crops with forest trees. It improves land productivity. It enhances soil and water conservation.
Silvopasture combines trees, forage crops, and livestock. It improves animal comfort and soil health. It increases farm profitability.
Green revolution was the agricultural transformation using high-yield varieties and fertilizers. It increased food production significantly. It improved food security.
Brown revolution refers to increased production of cocoa and leather. It strengthened agricultural industries. It supported rural livelihoods.
White revolution increased milk production through improved dairy practices. It made India a leading milk producer. It strengthened rural economy.
Blue revolution improved fish production through aquaculture development. It boosted seafood availability. It improved livelihoods of fishing communities.
Yellow revolution enhanced oilseed production. It reduced edible oil imports. It strengthened oil crop farming.
Soil mulching film is a plastic sheet placed over soil. It conserves moisture and prevents weed growth. It increases soil temperature.
Shade net farming uses net structures to reduce sunlight intensity. It protects crops from heat stress. It improves vegetable and flower quality.
Micro-irrigation supplies water in small amounts directly to roots. It reduces water loss. It increases irrigation efficiency.
Automatic irrigation controller uses sensors to regulate watering. It schedules irrigation based on soil moisture. It reduces water waste.
Crop stress index measures plant stress levels. Used in precision agriculture. Helps in timely crop management.
Fertigation tank mixes fertilizer with irrigation water. It ensures uniform nutrient supply. It improves fertilizer efficiency.
Tensiometer measures soil water tension. It shows how hard roots must work to extract water. Helps schedule irrigation.
Liming is the addition of lime to acidic soils. It raises soil pH. It improves nutrient availability.
Bio-remediation uses organisms to remove soil pollutants. It cleans contaminated land. It restores soil health.
Phytoremediation uses plants to absorb soil toxins. It is eco-friendly. It improves soil quality naturally.
Wind erosion is soil loss due to strong winds. It reduces fertility. Shelterbelts help control it.
Sheet erosion is uniform removal of topsoil by water. It is often unnoticed. It reduces soil productivity.
Rill erosion creates small channels in soil. It occurs due to surface runoff. It can develop into gullies.
Gully erosion forms deep channels in land. It causes severe land degradation. It is difficult to reverse.
Carbon farming increases carbon storage in soil. It reduces atmospheric CO₂. It improves soil fertility.
Soil carbon pool is the total carbon stored in soil. It improves soil structure. It supports climate mitigation.
Soil organic matter includes decomposed plant and animal materials. It improves soil fertility. It enhances water retention.
Crop carbon footprint measures greenhouse gases from crop production. Lower footprint indicates sustainable practices. Helps in climate planning.
Nano-fertilizers use nano-technology for nutrient delivery. They improve absorption efficiency. They reduce fertilizer loss.
Slow-release fertilizers release nutrients gradually. They reduce leaching losses. They provide long-term nutrition.
Controlled-release fertilizers deliver nutrients in measured amounts. They improve crop response. They reduce environmental impact.
Liquid fertilizers are nutrient solutions applied via irrigation or foliar spray. They provide quick nutrient uptake. They improve crop response.
Foliar feeding sprays nutrients directly on leaves. It provides fast nutrient correction. Used during nutrient deficiencies.
Starter fertilizers support early plant growth. They are placed close to seeds. They improve seedling establishment.
Band placement applies fertilizer in concentrated strips. It improves nutrient efficiency. It reduces fertilizer wastage.
Broadcast fertilization spreads nutrients uniformly over soil. It is simple to apply. It is less efficient than targeted methods.
Side dressing applies fertilizer beside growing plants. It provides nutrients during active growth. It improves crop yield.
Top dressing applies fertilizers on soil surface after crop emergence. It supports plant growth. Common for nitrogen fertilizers.
Soil nutrient mining occurs when crops remove more nutrients than replaced. It reduces soil fertility. Balanced fertilization prevents it.
Crop nutrient budget balances nutrient input and output. It ensures sustainability. It helps reduce pollution.
Soil water holding capacity is the soil’s ability to retain water. Influences drought resistance. Improved by organic matter.
Plant water use efficiency is biomass produced per unit of water used. Higher efficiency improves drought tolerance. Important in dry farming.
Soil infiltration capacity measures maximum water absorption rate. Affects irrigation efficiency. Improves with good soil structure.
Rainfall intensity is the amount of rain per unit time. High intensity increases erosion risk. Affects crop planning.
Effective rainfall is usable rainwater for crops. It excludes runoff losses. Important for irrigation planning.
Crop water productivity is yield per unit of water used. Higher values indicate efficient water use. Important in water-scarce regions.
Crop heat unit measures accumulated heat for crop development. Helps plan harvest time. Used in crop modeling.
Agro-climate resilience is the ability of farming systems to adapt to climate stress. It improves long-term stability. Achieved through diversification.
Climate mitigation farming reduces greenhouse gas emissions. It uses eco-friendly practices. Supports environmental sustainability.
Soil sealing is covering soil with impermeable materials. It reduces water absorption. It leads to land degradation.
Plant water stress index measures crop water deficit. Used in smart farming. Helps avoid yield loss.
Crop root depth determines water and nutrient exploration. Deeper roots improve drought tolerance. Important in crop selection.
Taproot system is a main rootot growing deep into soil. It anchors plants firmly. Improves water access.
Fibrous root system has many shallow roots. It absorbs surface nutrients. Common in grasses.
Stolon propagation uses horizontal stems to grow new plants. It is used in grasses. Supports vegetative reproduction.
Rhizome propagation uses underground stems for growth. It is common in ginger and turmeric. It is asexual reproduction.
Tillering is the formation of side shoots in crops. It increases plant population. Common in cereals.
Bolting is sudden stem elongation before flowering. It affects vegetable quality. Triggered by temperature changes.
Crop senescence is aging phase of plants. Leaves lose chlorophyll. Signals harvest readiness.
Physiological maturity is when seeds reach maximum dry weight. Harvesting at this stage ensures quality. Important for seed crops.
Economic threshold level is pest density at which control is needed. It minimizes unnecessary pesticide use. Used in IPM.
Damage threshold is pest level causing economic damage. It helps in decision-making. Prevents overuse of chemicals.
Biological threshold is pest density where population growth accelerates. Early intervention is effective. Used in pest prediction.
Stored grain pests damage harvested grains. They reduce food quality. Proper storage prevents infestation.
Fumigation uses gases to kill pests in storage. It protects stored grains. Requires safety precautions.
Hermetic storage is airtight grain storage. It prevents pest survival. It preserves grain quality.
Modified atmosphere storage controls oxygen and carbon dioxide levels. It extends shelf life. Used for fruits and grains.
Solar dryers use sunlight to dry crops. They reduce moisture content. They improve storage life.
Mechanical drying uses machines to remove moisture from crops. It is faster than sun drying. It improves quality.
Grain moisture meter measures water content in grains. It ensures safe storage. It reduces spoilage risk.
Harvest index is the economic yield to total biomass ratio. Higher index means efficient crop. Used in breeding.
Crop water stress occurs due to insufficient water. It reduces yield. Proper irrigation prevents it.
Yield gap is the difference between potential and actual yield. It indicates management inefficiency. Reducing gap improves productivity.
Farm diversification involves multiple farm activities. It reduces financial risk. It stabilizes income.
Agro-processing converts raw crops into value-added products. It increases shelf life. It boosts farmer income.
Rural entrepreneurship involves business activities in rural areas. It creates employment. It strengthens rural economy.
Farm mechanization level shows use of machines in agriculture. Higher level improves efficiency. Reduces labor dependency.
Custom hiring center rents farm machinery to farmers. It reduces investment burden. Supports small farmers.
Agro-service center provides farming inputs and advice. It supports farmers. Improves productivity.
Seed replacement rate measures use of certified seeds. Higher rate improves yield. It ensures genetic purity.
Crop phenotyping measures plant traits. It helps select improved varieties. Used in research.
Participatory plant breeding involves farmers in crop improvement. It ensures local suitability. Strengthens farmer-research link.
Agro-climatic risk refers to crop losses caused by unpredictable weather conditions. It affects farm productivity. Risk management includes crop insurance and diversification.
Weather-based crop insurance compensates farmers for losses due to weather extremes. It reduces financial risk. It encourages stable agricultural production.
Agro-met advisory provides farmers with weather-based farming advice. It helps optimize sowing and irrigation. It reduces crop failure risk.
Drought proofing involves practices that reduce the impact of water scarcity. Techniques include mulching and water harvesting. It improves crop survival.
Flood-resistant varieties are crops that tolerate submerged conditions. They survive waterlogging better. Useful in flood-prone areas.
Salinity tolerant crops can grow in high salt soils. They reduce yield loss in degraded lands. Useful for coastal and arid regions.
Heat tolerant varieties withstand high temperatures. They maintain yield under climatic stress. Important under global warming.
Cold tolerant varieties survive low temperatures. They prevent frost damage. Used in high-altitude farming.
Seed hardening is a pre-sowing treatment to improve drought tolerance. It strengthens early growth. It increases crop resilience.
Plant acclimatization helps plants adapt to environmental changes. It improves survival rates. Common in nursery practices.
Crop standby irrigation is watering given during dry spells. It protects crops from moisture stress. It stabilizes yield.
Contingency crop planning involves alternate crop strategies during climate stress. It reduces crop failure risk. Used during late monsoons.
Variable rate technology applies inputs based on field variability. It minimizes waste. It increases efficiency.
Soil electrical conductivity measures soil salinity. It helps identify problem zones. Guides soil management.
Crop health index shows the condition of plants. It uses vegetation data. Supports precision farming decisions.
Autonomous tractors operate without human drivers. They increase efficiency. Used in large-scale agriculture.
Smart soil probes measure moisture and temperature. They provide real-time data. Used in modern irrigation systems.
Climate forecasting models predict future weather patterns. They assist in farm planning. Reduce climate-related risks.
Internet of Farming connects farm devices through the internet. It enables remote monitoring. Supports digital agriculture.
Remote irrigation management controls irrigation from distance. It saves labor and water. Increases irrigation efficiency.
Smart fertigation systems automate nutrient delivery. They optimize fertilizer use. Reduce nutrient losses.
Early pest warning system predicts pest outbreaks. It alerts farmers in advance. Reduces crop loss.
Disease forecasting models predict plant diseases. They enable timely treatment. Improve crop protection.
Automated greenhouse lighting adjusts light levels. It optimizes plant growth. Supports year-round production.
Controlled atmosphere greenhouse regulates gases and temperature. It improves crop quality. Enhances yield consistency.
Nutrient film technique is a hydroponic system where nutrients flow as a thin film. Roots absorb nutrients efficiently. Suitable for leafy vegetables.
Aeroponics grows plants in air using nutrient mist. It uses very little water. Produces fast growth rates.
Soilless cultivation grows plants without traditional soil. It uses organic or synthetic media. Improves resource efficiency.
Plant tissue culture grows plants from small tissues. It produces disease-free plants. Used for rapid multiplication.
Micropropagation is rapid plant multiplication in labs. It ensures genetic uniformity. Used for commercial crops.
Somatic embryogenesis produces embryos from body cells. It is used in plant cloning. Helps in crop improvement.
Gene editing modifies plant DNA for better traits. It improves yield and resistance. Supports modern breeding.
Genetically modified crops have altered genes. They resist pests and stress. Increase productivity.
Marker assisted selection uses genetic markers to improve crops. It speeds breeding process. Enhances accuracy.
Seed priming is controlled hydration of seeds. It improves germination speed. Strengthens early seedling growth.
Embryo rescue grows embryos in artificial media. It saves hybrids. Used in advanced plant breeding.
Double cropping grows two crops in one year. It maximizes land use. Increases farm income.
Triple cropping grows three crops in a year. It increases production intensity. Requires good irrigation.
Border cropping plants protective crops around main fields. It reduces pest invasion. Improves field stability.
Parallel cropping grows crops side by side. It reduces competition. Improves efficiency.
Mixed cropping system grows two crops together randomly. It reduces total crop failure risk. Improves biodiversity.
Sequential cropping grows crops one after another. It maintains continuous land use. Improves productivity.
Multi-tier cropping grows crops of different heights. It increases resource utilization. Common in orchards.
Living mulch uses cover crops as mulch. It reduces weeds. Improves soil health.
Biological seed treatment uses beneficial microbes. It protects against diseases. Improves germination.
Seed exudates are substances released during germination. They attract beneficial microbes. Aid early plant growth.
Rhizobacteria live near plant roots. They promote growth. Improve nutrient availability.
These bacteria enhance plant development. They improve root growth. Increase stress resistance.
Endophytes are microorganisms living inside plant tissues. They improve plant resistance. Enhance growth.
Compost tea is a liquid extract of compost. It nourishes plants. Improves microbial population.
Vermiwash is liquid from vermicompost. It contains nutrients and hormones. Acts as liquid fertilizer.
Green leaf manuring uses fresh plant leaves to enrich soil. It increases organic matter. Improves fertility.
Liquid biofertilizers contain beneficial microbes. They are easy to apply. Improve nutrient uptake.
Bio-inoculants introduce beneficial microbes into soil. They enhance plant growth. Reduce chemical fertilizer use.
Plant based pesticides are derived from plants. They are eco-friendly. Safe for beneficial insects.
Microbial pesticides use bacteria or fungi to kill pests. They are environment-friendly. Target specific pests.
Trap pheromones attract pests into traps. They reduce pest population. Used in integrated pest control.
Sticky traps capture flying pests. They help in pest monitoring. Reduce insect numbers.
Light traps use light to attract insects. They are used for pest control. Reduce chemical pesticide need.
Bird perches encourage predatory birds. They help control pests naturally. Promote eco-friendly farming.
Biological weed control uses natural enemies to suppress weeds. It minimizes chemical use. Supports sustainable farming.
Cover crop termination involves removing cover crops before main crops. It releases nutrients. Improves soil conditions.
Mulch roller flattens cover crops onto soil. It creates natural mulch. Reduces weed growth.
Crop residue incorporator mixes crop residues into soil. It increases organic matter. Improves soil structure.
Zero till seed drill plants seeds without plowing. It reduces soil disturbance. Improves soil health.
Conservation agriculture minimizes soil disturbance. Uses cover crops. Improves sustainability.
Climate resilient agriculture adapts farming to climate change. Uses tolerant crops. Protects long-term productivity.
Low input agriculture reduces external chemical use. Relies on natural resources. Supports eco-farming.
Natural farming inputs include cow dung-based formulations. They replace synthetic fertilizers. Reduce farming cost.
Indigenous technical knowledge is traditional farming wisdom. It supports sustainable practices. Preserves cultural heritage.
Community seed saving involves local seed conservation. It preserves native varieties. Improves resilience.
Farmer field school is a learning approach in farming. It teaches through practical experience. Improves farm skills.
Extension services provide technical support to farmers. They improve knowledge. Increase agricultural productivity.
Agri start-ups are new agricultural technology businesses. They introduce innovation. Improve farm efficiency.
Agri entrepreneurship creates agribusiness ventures. It increases rural employment. Strengthens economy.
Vertical integration controls multiple production stages. It improves efficiency. Reduces dependency on middlemen.
Contract farming is agreement between farmers and companies. It assures market and price. Reduces marketing risk.
Warehouse receipt system allows farmers to store crops and get loans. It prevents distress sale. Improves financial security.
Commodity grading standards define quality benchmarks. They improve market transparency. Help farmers earn better prices.
Farm branding creates unique identity of farm produce. It increases market value. Helps in direct marketing.
Organic labeling certifies chemical-free products. It builds consumer trust. Increases market demand.
Traceability system tracks food from farm to consumer. It ensures quality and safety. Prevents fraud.
Agri export promotion supports international sales. It improves farmer income. Strengthens national economy.
Trade facilitation simplifies agricultural exports. It reduces delays. Improves competitiveness.
Crop loss assessment evaluates damage after disasters. It helps insurance claims. Guides compensation.
Disaster resilient farming reduces vulnerability to disasters. Uses strong infrastructure. Secures food production.
Agro disaster preparedness includes plans for floods and droughts. It minimizes losses. Protects farmer livelihoods.
Food traceability tracks food safety. It ensures quality. Protects consumer health.
